Jim,
I reply within the body of your mail....

Jim Gilbert wrote:
> Cary,
> Interesting question... my initial thoughts without any effort at research:
> 
> I think that I picked up the Mito Shoami designation from Bob Haynes 
> years ago.  The term does appear in his auction catalogs, although that 
> is not sufficient grounds for proving the existence of the group.  
> Calling something "nameless shiiremono" would of course not advance a sale.
> 
> "Tetsu no Isho - Mito-To to Tosogu no Meihin" is indeed the book I was 
> thinking of.  Of course we wouldn't expect to see the low quality 
> examples from any group or region illustrated or referenced.  So the 
> absence of mention is not necessarily proof of non-existence.
> 
I agree that the very title which includes the word
Meihin (distinguished works) would exempt the inclusion
of lower class items (shiiremono).
However, since the book is quite a comprehensive study,
I am assuming that if there were Shoami works produced there
(i.e.. signed Suifu ju Shoami xxxx) they would have included
the best examples known.

> I don't believe that I have ever seen a kanteisho to Mito Shoami.  
> However, when I assisted Hagihara-sensei at last year's shinsa in Jersey 
> City, the so-called "Mito Shoami" type examples submitted were all 
> rejected as "poor quality work," so there was no opportunity for such an 
> attribution to be made on an NTHK kanteisho.  If that is the standard 
> judgment of the NBTHK, we would not expect to see any Mito Shoami 
> kanteisho at all, even if the group existed.

> I do not recall seeing any examples signed Mito Shoami.  I have seen 
> examples signed Aizu ju Shoami and I have seen many mumei pieces, 
> although of better quality than the "Mito Shoami" examples, attributed 
> to Aizu Shoami. 


I'm relieved in a way that your empirical
observations coincide with mine.
I was wondering if indeed Hagihara sensei
had in fact papered some tsuba to "Mito Shoami".
I would have very much liked to see an example of
what he considered worthy of papering as such.
As you know, I have great respect for his opinions.


> I assume you can picture the type of tsuba that we have been calling 
> Mito Shoami.  There are many of them in the US and the type is quite 
> uniform.  Who do you think made all of those tsuba?  Serious question.
> 
Indeed I do.
Serious answer - Anonymous (no shame in that).
Museums often use that term in other fields in cases in which
a work is simply non-attributable to a specific artist or school.


> The merit of the usage of the term Mito Shoami deserves follow up.  I 
> think that we'll find that these guards are indeed ignored as shiiremono 
> and are not likely to be documented or recognized by Japanese sources.  
> Again, interesting observation.
> 
> Jim
> 
> 
> 
>   Jim, Alan, Rich et al.
> 
>   My remarks may be radical and heretical considering
>   how casually the term "Mito Shoami" is bandied about
>   on this list and others.
> 
>   I have never seen a tsuba or other kodogu attributed
>   to Mito Shoami. I am of the opinion that Shoami
>   artisans were not productive there.
> 
>   There are certainly pieces that have papered to just Mito.
>   But none that I know of to Mito Shoami,
>   in which case the basic premise is incorrect.
> 
>   Jim,
>   The book you are referring to I presume is titled:
>   Tetsu no Isho - Mito-To to Tosogu no Meihin (1996).
>   Ibaraki Prefectural Historical Museum.
> 
>   In section II - Mito Kinko no Tosogu,
>   The introductory text records prominent individuals
>   and groups that were active in Mito (Hitachi province).
>   Among them:
>   Gunji Yogoro
>   Yatabe Tsuji
>   Seiryuken Ha
>   Ichiryu (Hitotsuyanagi) Ha
>   Tamagawa Ha
>   Uchikoshi Ha
>   Yasuchika Ha (from the 4th gen. Yasuchika)
>   Saotome and Myochin.
>   And of course, Hagiya Shohei (Katsuhira) and Unno Shomin.
> 
> 
>   NO mention of Shoami in Mito.
> 
>   Checking Haynes- Tsuba, An Aesthetic Study.
>   Under the section dealing with SHOAMI he mentions:
>   Kyo Shoami, Awa Shoami, Bizen Shoami, Iyo Shoami,
>   Aizu Shoami, Shonai Shoami, Akita Shoami,
>   Bushu (Edo) Shoami & Sakushu (Mimasaka) Shoami.
>   In addition he adds individuals who signed:
>   Oshu Shoami, Soshu (Odawara) Shoami, Seishu (Ise) Shoami,
>   Osaka (Settsu) Shoami, Banshu (Harima) Shoami,
>   Inshu (Inaba) Shoami & Kurume (Chikugo) Shoami.
> 
>   Again NO mention of Mito Shoami.
> 
>   I have never liked the term Mito Shoami
>   and have never used it. This thread presented
>   an opportunity to research the issue
>   to see if my opinion had any basis.
> 
>   Can anyone document a piece that has been
>   authoritatively classified as Mito Shoami
>   or have we been perpetuating a fallacy?
>

>   Jim Gilbert wrote:
>   > Rich & all,
>   > Alan is definitely correct.  While not always to my personal taste,
>   > there were a number of Mito lines producing very high quality 
> fittings. 
>   > Several of these Mito lineage founders were students of leading kinko
>   > artists.  No doubt the Mito Tokugawa branch family (with 350,000 koku
>   > revenue) and their retainers were responsible for supporting these many
>   > skilled workers.
>   >
>   > The standardized plates, designs taken from copy books, large scale
>   > production and relatively poor quality are characteristics of the Mito
>   > Shoami.  Aizu Shoami workers did a lot of the same.
>   >
>   > There are some rather poor quality, unsigned Mito tsuba as well.  It's
>   > probably possible to find a group of better than average Mito Shoami
>   > work that exceeds the quality of the bottom of Mito production.  These
>   > lesser pieces are probably the source of the confusion between Mito and
>   > Mito Shoami.  I have seen some fairly insipid mumei tsuba with 
> kanteisho
>   > to Mito.
>   >
>   > It's true that better Mito workers did copy Nara, Hamano and others, 
> but
>   > their copy work is nothing like the Mito Shoami stuff after the Nara
>   > style.  If anything the workmanship of the Mito copies is a bit over 
> the
>   > top compared with the originals.  It's also usually signed by the maker.
>   >
>   > There was a book on published 5-10 years ago on Mito swords and 
> tosogu. 
>   > Mine is out on loan and I don't remember the title or author's name. 
>   > Does anyone have one handy?  In any event, that's a good book to look
>   > through to get a feel for the better Mito work.
>   >
>   > Jim
>   >
>   >
>   >
>   >   Rich,
>   >   I think you are mistaken in your appraisal of Mito work, the Mito 
> Shoami
>   >   never achieved much prominence but the Mito Kinko are among the best
>   > artists
>   >   who ever made fittings, particularly in the late Edo/Meiji periods 
> with
>   >   artists like Hagiya Katsuhei and Unno Shomin. They were also very able
>   >   copyists, I remember Mr Ono some years ago showed me a well known 
> Somin
>   >   kozuka of a horse (seen from the rear) in takazogan, I asked him how
>   > to tell
>   >   the real thing from a Mito copy, he said the only difference was that
>   > in the
>   >   copy the horse stood more proud, or was it the other way around?
>   >   Alan
